reviewText:
Nope.

Look guys, this is a linear game with literally 4 screens, no animations, and ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• voiceovers.
Just because you jumble the pieces around each playthrough doesn't make the 10 minutes it takes to complete it any more fun or humorous". Unless you're a person who considers replacing a dragon with a butter knife the pinnacle of hilarity."
voteText: 55 of 74 people (74%) found this review helpful 11 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Developed by: Fancy Fish Games
Achievements: Yes
Steam Workshop: Yes

Story:

ADventure Lib is set in a medieval world and you are a hero who embarks on an adventure to save the kingdom; however who/what you and every other thing in the kingdom is/are is totally shuffled when you start playing causing some hilarious moments.

Gameplay:

Start the game with a shuffle button; every character and item is randomized but still keeps their assigned roles. (IE. In my first play through the king is a butter knife and the hero is a potato)
Classic adventure gaming returns with looking at items, collecting items, combining items and using items. At least in this game the ridiculousness of that classic system is highlighted but the completely insane randomization
Because of this most of the game play is just trying to find the right tool for the job at hand, whether it‚Äôs fighting the PLUNGER or helping the CHICKEN. Results may vary.
There are secrets to be found, from the charming Easter Egg/Throwbacks in the backgrounds or the collectables that are a little tougher to find, sometimes.
One of the coolest features of ADventure Lib is the ability to create your own assets to put in the game! An easy to use interface lets you provide the image (I used a transparent PNG and it looked great) record the word yourself and it gets added to the game with everything else.
Steam Workshop is also integrated so you can share your creations with everyone. Whatever they may be. We all know what‚Äôs coming.
The game is admittedly on the shorter side but that actually works for me; the best part of this game is shuffling the entire game into a new experience and playing with new crazy stuff going on. That said, the ending I received initially was fairly abrupt and I am not 100% sure if there is a ‚Äúgood‚Äù ending that you can receive on subsequent plays.
All in all there isn‚Äôt much that you wont be able to figure out with a light application of intelligence
and patience. This isn‚Äôt Dark Souls; this is a lighthearted adventure and just a good bit of silly fun.

Graphics:

ADventure Lib, for being a simple 2D exploration game, manages to look really clean and well put together.
It looks they way you would expect, being light on the animation side with stuff bobbing around the screen. This helps when you add your own content it fits in perfectly.
Able to change character‚Äôs two main color schemes anytime

Sound:

Music and SFX: The sound effects and music are just fine. No problems with them; nothing special in that regard.  It all blends into the game play well.
Voice Acting: This game is fully and independently voice acted. It is half of the charm, really! Its nice that they took the time to do this even if it was done by people who are new to the industry. Only a couple lines came off as recorded out of place but it was hard to notice amongst the crazy dialog. Also: If you add an asset to the game you can count yourself as a voice actor as well. üòÄ

Final Verdict:

ADventure Lib is a light-hearted and loving tribute to the ‚Äúuse X on Y‚Äù genre. While it is small in scale I had no technical issues playing it and had a lot of fun working out the puzzles (basic as they are). Adults and kids alike would have a fun time with all the goofy situations that arise in this game and at the price it‚Äôs damn near risk-free to give it a try. It is a little short but it‚Äôs fun to replay (especially after adding new characters/items to the game!).

Disclaimer: I was provided a copy of this game for review purposes.  My opinions are my own.

reviewText:
ADventure Lib is a very entertaining, funny and short experience.
A Gameplay & Review video showcasing the features I'm about to talk about:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GqY4WZ_SvMk

When you start the game, all objects and characters in the world are shuffled with the game's database of objects.
That means the character you play as could be a potato, and you're trying to save toilet from a fire-breathing plunger.

The gameplay is incredibly simplistic. You have a Look" action that gives you a hint what the object is meant to be used for. E.g "This rope is very sharp" so you know to use it as a sword. You also have your primary action which is to use or talk to objects/characters.

There's the option to have voice acting
date: which is decent and funny. Accompanied by some fun music.\nThe puzzles are incredibly easy to solve
recommended: so don't expect anything harder.\n\nA cool feature is the ability to import your own objects and characters into the game. You can import any picture you like
hoursPlayed: accompanied with an audio file of you choosing (or you can record it within the game using your microphone) so that the game will pronounce your object during voice acting sequences. You can also upload your created objects into Steam workshop. Obviously this helps refresh the game a few times if you want to have a laugh with a friend.\n\nAgain
voteText: if you go into this game knowing that it's very short
helpfulPercent: but its main purpose is to make you laugh
votesHelpful: then you'll have a good time."

reviewText:
https://youtu.be/Z4XO_lEU6JM

ADventure Lib is essentially an adventure game in the form of Madlibs. This isn't that deep a title, really. It's a basic story that relies on random objects in place of the real things. Fire breathing princesses instead of a dragon, kitten instead of a plunger, toilets are keys... Basic rules, limited possibilities.

Really, this is something I'd play with my kids (if I had any) moreso than play myself. It bored me at first, but some of the bad voice acting and phrasing due to said libs made it worth playing (as you'll see in the video). But, it's only good for one play. Hopefully the developer releases more stories as free updates, and more people take advantage of the steam workshop option, to increase replay value.

Even though it's maybe one playthrough at 35-40 minutes max, I suggest it. Fun little time waster, and a good way to spend time with your kids.

This game was reviewed with a key from the developer

Sadly, despite a laugh or two being gotten through the random generation at the use of _______(object) and ________ (different object) and Mad Libs like portion of it, and the game having potential like ____ (game with reasonable potential) with the steam workshop with the objects you can add and add your voice too in an _______ (adjective) tone, the main plot is very short like a ____ (noun) and is the only scenario. Like a list of Mad Libs you'd do as a kid when you were ______ (adverb), you really don't want to do the same story over and over again or it'll cause you to _____ (verb). It's got potential if it added those _______ (adjective) elements, but right now, I can't recommend as there's not a lot of replayability and there's a real lack of _____ (Noun). Even for two bucks, I don't think I can recommend the experience right now unless you were really into the apperance of _____ (Proper Noun). I was able to play through the story twice, and at the hours played here, that it an indication of what I'm talking about.

Lists:

+:
It can be comical with the right combinations of things.
Like the integration of the Steam workshop and voice portions with it.
-:
Unfortunately, the one campaign is too short. Not enough for replayability.
Really needed different scenarios in order to truly work. Even at a higher cost.
The tone really needed to be changed around for words to sell the story.
Sometimes, the words needed a bit more specific information in order to truly work. It became a game of guessing after a while.
It's one of those games that a higher price tag and more content made a lot more sense more then anything else.

reviewText: The premise alone makes a sufficient selling point for this game. Every time you play through the story, important objects are completely randomised, making for completely absurd and hilarious combinations. Just look at the player-uploaded screenshots in the community hub, and you'll see what I mean.\nThe voice acting may be annoying for some, but it is easily mutable. The story is very short, but very replayable, and the developer has promised that another story is on the way.\nIt can get tricky to keep track of what does what, but fortunately there's a look at" button which gives you a hint as to what to do. And despite the various possible combinations
date: there is a limited number of objects in the library. But hey
recommended: that's what the workshop is for.\n\nNow if you'll excuse me
hoursPlayed: I have to sit up at the kitten to eat my princesses."

reviewText:
ADventure Lib is a moneygrab, and an awful one at that. It's not often you stumble across something as bad as this.

I had read all the negative reviews for this game and wanted to give it a try because sometimes people can be a little over the top when it comes to writing something bad about a game, but in this case, every single one was justified. It doesn't matter how mad or wacky the developers said they tried to make the game, it is a lie. There is no effort put into the making of this at all. I truly feel sorry for the developers if it took them longer  to make than the twelve minutes I put into getting all of the achievements.

In ADventure Lib you play a hero who has to find a great treasure to prove himself to the king. There is a pool of words that are scrambled into the game and will be randomly assigned to certain items. These are words like 'key, butter, Charles, plunger, knife etc.'. Every time you begin a new game everything will be re-randomized using the same pool. The story remains the same, the characters remain the same, the only thing that changes from playthrough to playthrough is which item gets called what.
Being a point and click this makes ADventure Lib a pain in the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• to play. Point and click games rely on you combining different items with each other, as does this, except these items are randomly named so the entire game is trying every single item with something else until something works. All future playthroughs will be boring as once you know where you find the item you'll know what it is meant to be and where it is meant to be used.

Every achievement can be found in one single playthrough and can be gotten within 15 minutes with ease, though there is nothing to make you want to get them besides the fact you actually wasted money on this and feel like you NEED something in return.
The voice acting is poor, the graphics are basic and the story is terrible. There is no re-playability, and no fun to be had the first time you play either.

There MAY have been a good idea somewhere here but the lack of effort from the developers have left this game completely worthless.

ADventure Lib truly is a game that doesn't ever need to be played. I hope that no-one spends their money on this and the developers should feel ashamed charging $2 for this mess of a game. I know I'll be avoiding anything Fancy Fish Games makes in the future, even if it's from a cheap bundle.

reviewText:
When I was a tyke I used to program mad libs in BASIC and many laughs were had.

This game is a similar thing. There's a basic storyline and a set of objects that get shuffled, then you go through the story that way. The game is very short right now, but it has workshop support and the dev is working on releasing a storyline editor for the next update.

Create lots of random things and new stories in which to see them out of place.

For $2 it's a fun toy. Check it out.

reviewText: This game is an interesting concept that would potentially be a fun free flash game that could garner some mild interest. It is NOT, however, anything worth paying money for. There's maybe 20 minutes of gameplay at best, the voice acting is sub-par, the alleged wackiness" and "comedy" is one joke repeated over and over again
date: and the actual gameplay is pretty horrendous. It suffers from the point & click disaster of the most efficient strategy being to use everything on everything else - not only because the item pool is tiny
recommended: but also because most of the solutions seem completely arbitrary. Additionally
hoursPlayed: most of the interaction buttons are hard to actually trigger - you can be standing right on top of a character you need to talk to and still spend more time wiggling around trying to get the "Talk" button to show up than you spent working out the actual puzzle. This is presumably because the character sprites changes every playthrough
voteText: but that doesn't make the gameplay any more enjoyable.\n\nAll in all
helpfulPercent: it's an okay idea that was executed far too poorly to warrant charging for. I got this game for $0.40 from a Groupees bundle and I'm still not sure if it was worth the money."

reviewText:
Take an everyday standard adventure and mix up all of the nouns and you get 'ADventure Lib' where illogical solutions are the only way to proceed.

The concept is fun, fresh and silly making it a great game for children who would play the game multiple times to see the different combinations.  While being fully voiced helps the appeal for young players the voice work is spotty at times not just in performance but also recording quality.  Steam workshop support also allows players to add new words to the pool.

Due to the random nature of the game, player experience will vary greatly depending on the shuffle.  Overall this game does a lot right and if it polished up some of it's rough spots it'd be a great kids game.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
A very strange game. This is a very classic knight, dragon, princess, magic sword, son on and so on story but with every element mixed up - thus the king is a potato, the fire breathing dragon is now a fire breahing fish, butter knife lays out plunger eggs so on and so forth.

Strange game indeed, it takes about 20-30 minutes to finish this short game.

I don't know whether I would play it again because the next playthrough is basically the same. If you can play this game then give it a go but I would not buy it.

reviewText: Cute little adventure game that hooked me in as I am a sucker/fan of Madlibs.  Also a nice jab at older adventure games that don't particularly make sense in the puzzle solving.   Overall, a very easy adventure that basically requires you to pick up items (read what they really are/do), occasionally combine them and use them at the appropriate time.  Short and pretty impossible to get lost.  Each play through mixs up the props but the adventure" elements are the same so replays go very quick!  I played through a few times mainly waiting for trading card drops
recommended: I doubt I would play again. Fun for what it was though."

reviewText: This seems like a game someone would enjoy after a long night of drinking or sleep deprivation, but fully sober and awake it isn't very amusing.
